This scientific quest to find â€œmissingâ€ memories is changing the way we think about the brain.  Neuroscientist Nathan Rose and his colleagues at the University of Wisconsin recently lost track of a memory.     I mean that literally. One minute, they saw a trace of a memory â€œlight upâ€ in an fMRI scan. In the next minute it was gone. And in this one simple observation, Rose and his colleagues are challenging a   scientific belief about how the brain works. And can open to door to new understanding of why we remember, and why we forget. The curious case of the â€œmissingâ€ memory Rose lost the memory during a fairly simple experiment. Participants were brought into the lab and given an image of a face and a separate name to memorize. They were told theyâ€™d later be tested on their ability to recognize that name and that face. All the while, a fMRI scanner was peering into their brains. An artificial intelligence program then used the fMRI images to distinguish between when the participants were thinking about the face, and when they were thinking about the name. When participants were asked to recall either the face or the name, the computer program could â€œseeâ€ them thinking about each.     But then the participants underwent a different test. And this is where things get weird.     The participants were told that they were only going to be tested on their memory of the face and didnâ€™t need to remember the name. When that happened, it was like a switch turned off in the participantsâ€™ brains. The fMRI could no longer â€œseeâ€ the memory of the name. It was â€œas if the item has been forgotten,â€ Rose says.  Except hereâ€™s the really surprising part: The name wasnâ€™t actually forgotten. The participants could still remember it later on when prompted again. The memory was still there  â€”   there was just no observable trace of it in the brain.     This may sound like a minor observation, but it could fundamentally change the way neuroscientists think about how the brain works. The study, published today in Science, shows thereâ€™s a whole â€œdarkâ€ brain activity that neuroscientists canâ€™t see with current neuroimaging technology. And if scientists can better understand this dark network of memories, perhaps they can find ways to make us retain more information, or retrieve lost memories.  The conventional wisdom on working memory may be wrong            Working memory is the function of our brain that holds information that we need immediately  â€”   if someone tells you the names of the hosts before you walk into a party, thatâ€™s where you keep them. Think of it like the desktop on your computer. Itâ€™s where you bring   memories out of deep storage to work on them. Itâ€™s also where new information is first stored in your brain before it can be filed away. Working memory is the space where we work on our thoughts and put them to use. For a long time, neuroscientists thought they knew how working memory works. Based on neuroimaging studies, it seemed that working memory was always associated with a flurry of neural activity.     â€œThe inference, then, was that a   memory existed only if it produced some sustained brain activity that could be identified with our various forms of neuroscience measurement methods  â€”   including functional neuroimaging such as fMRI,â€ Jarrod   a neuroscientist at the University of Texas Austin, explains. If there is no trace of a thought in a brain scan, it implies the thought is no longer there. Or that fMRIs  â€”   which are key tool of neuroscience research  â€”   donâ€™t tell us all that much about the working of the brain.  What Roseâ€™s new study suggests is that the memory is still there in the absence of any observable neural activity. â€œ[Itâ€™s] a big deal because people assumed elevated activity is how [working] memories are stored,â€ Bradley Postle, a study   says. (And itâ€™s not the case that the memories were simply transferred to   storage.) â€œThis line of research is a big deal,â€ Nelson Cowan, a psychologist who studies memory at the University of Missouri Columbia who was not involved in this study, tells me. â€œThis kind of work could be helpful in diagnosing whatâ€™s going on when a person cannot remember something you just presented to them. â€ Because thereâ€™s a huge difference in treatment approaches for a patient who does not have the memory stored somewhere in her brain, and a patient who does have that memory stored somewhere, perhaps silently, but just cannot call it to attention.  Itâ€™s also a big deal because of what Rose and his colleagues did next. They brought that silent memory back to life with a zap of magnetic radiation.  The memories can be temporarily restored  Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) is a neuroscience tool that sends pulses of magnetic radiation to temporarily â€œturn onâ€ or â€œturn offâ€ a personâ€™s neural circuits. â€œFor example, if find your thumb area in your left motor cortex, and if I [turn on TMS] I can cause your thumb to twitch,â€ Rose says. Guided by machine learning, Roseâ€™s team was able to train the TMS to locate areas of the brain where participants were storing the memory of the face or the name. Simply put, Rose and his colleagues devised a way to turn back on the memory that had grown silent.     When they turned on the TMS on the silent memory, an EEG brain scan showed activation in the area of the brain associated with that memory. So they ran the memory trial again, zapping people with TMS when a memory became silent. When the TMS was on, it seemed like the participants became confused about which item  â€”   the face or the name  â€”   they were supposed to remember, and they performed worse on the test. Some of Roseâ€™s colleagues jokingly called it the â€œFrankenstein effect,â€ suggesting they brought this memory back to life.  Whatâ€™s more, Rose and his colleagues found evidence that these â€œsilentâ€ memories also get silently â€œdeletedâ€ when person is told they no longer need the information.  So, to use the computer analogy again, itâ€™s like these working memories, as with a computer, can either be brought out of recycling or they can be deleted when no longer needed. And this whole process happens beyond the detections of typical neuroscience research tools. Itâ€™s a part of the brainâ€™s â€œoperating systemâ€ that weâ€™ve never seen before. As for the ability of TMS to reactivate forgotten memories in patients, Rose says thatâ€™s still a   idea. â€œItâ€™s going to be hard to avoid having the [study] spinned as â€˜TMS can bring your memories back,â€™ which is going far beyond what weâ€™re showing,â€ he says. Itâ€™s better to think of the TMS more as sonar, pinging the brain to see if the memory is even in there. Where do the silent memories go?            One theory is that the brain is constantly and silently reorganizing its neural networks to hold the impression of these memories, but keeps them inactive. Thatâ€™s roughly how neuroscience thinks   memory storage works. But these results are making Rose wonder if thatâ€™s how many systems of the brain work: that they are constantly moving thoughts from â€œactiveâ€ states to â€œsilentâ€ states, possibly by reorganizing the connections in the brain.     Christos Constantinidis, a neuroscience researcher at Wake Forrest University, says Roseâ€™s results donâ€™t negate the importance of neural firing in working memory, but that they suggest the neural firing and this â€œsilentâ€ process work together to make the brain more efficient. â€œThere are some instances where [sustained activity] may not be enough or may not be efficient,â€ he says. â€œThis silent mechanism bridges the gap. â€ Thereâ€™s also an alternative explanation for what happens: The brain still is firing neurons to sustain the memory, but they are too few in number for brain scans to detect. (There can be hundreds of thousands of neurons in a single voxel, the smallest unit of brain activity a fMRI can detect).  Overall, this new study is a reminder neuroscience is just starting to understand the brain, and itâ€™s a recognition that the typical tools of neuroscience  â€”   fMRI, EEG, all of the tools that depend on electrical signals or blood flow  â€”   just canâ€™t see many of the brainâ€™s processes. And that means weâ€™re just scratching the surface in terms of our observations about the brain. Itâ€™s still mostly a black box.  â€œJust showing one part of the brain â€˜light upâ€™ and inferring thatâ€™s where the item [memory] is  â€”   thatâ€™s a rudimentary idea,â€ Rose says.  â€œThe brain is the most complicated object that we know of in the universe,â€ Postle says. Weâ€™re going to have to be cleverer in our methods if we ever want to fully understand it.

The Clintons and the press are caught in a pointless, toxic cycle of scandal.  In retrospect, it seems almost too perfect that the most notable scandal of the Obama administration, the one that necessitated a public statement from the director of the FBI, was about Hillary Clinton rather than Barack Obama. Or maybe it was one of two somewhat notable scandals, along with Benghazi  â€”   another case where the scrutiny on Clinton was far greater than on the actual president.    It makes sense because the Clintons have, since even before Bill Clinton won the Democratic nomination in 1992, been magnets for scandal, many of them   nothings. When their close friend killed himself, they were accused of murder. When they lost money on a bad real estate deal that a friend who turned out to be a con artist suckered them into, it triggered a federal investigation, culminating in Clintonâ€™s impeachment for completely unrelated conduct. When they tried to clean up a White House office that the FBI was investigating for financial improprieties, the independent counsel wound up looking into their actions. So of course when Clinton joined Obamaâ€™s administration, similar   would follow. But it also makes sense because Obama has been almost entirely immune to this kind of imbroglio. The 2008 presidential campaign made him defend his past contact with Weather Underground militant Bill Ayers, his ties to   Chicago developer Tony Rezko, and his attendance at Jeremiah Wrightâ€™s fiery,   conspiracy theory â€”  touting sermons at Trinity Church. But none of those stuck. The Wright incident instead led to the best speech of Obamaâ€™s career, arguably helping him secure the Democratic nomination. None of these scandals have carried into his administration at all. What few scandals there have been have either involved people far enough down the federal government org chart such that Obama was barely implicated (â€Fast & Furious,â€ the IRS scandal, the VA scandal) or were so transparently ridiculous that they didnâ€™t hurt Obama at all (the â€birtherâ€ conspiracy theories being the canonical example).    So while Clinton faced the typical barrage of attacks while in the Obama administration, Obama himself is emerging from his eight years in office entirely untainted by scandal, to a degree matched by few presidents in history.    One way to read this is that Obama is unusually clean and the Clintons usually sketchy in their dealings. Another is that the Clintons were targets of an unusually intense smear campaign. The reality is a mix: The Clintons really were unfairly targeted in the early 1990s, but the experience has left them sufficiently jaded and paranoid that they think their own conduct is irrelevant to whether theyâ€™ll be targeted. That leads to carelessness, which in turn leads to more scandals, and on and on the cycle goes. Why is Clinton so   and Obama so  ?             There are two ways to interpret the discrepancy between the Clintonsâ€™ propensity for attracting scandals and Obamaâ€™s seeming immunity to them. One, which youâ€™ll hear Clinton loyalists voice, is that thereâ€™s a double standard, that the Clintons get battered for offenses that would barely raise an eyebrow coming from any other politician, including Obama. On that interpretation, the email scandal was just another example of how the Clintons just canâ€™t catch a break. Even when thereâ€™s a totally different Democrat in the White House, the guns are still trained on them.    The other interpretation, which youâ€™ll hear Obama loyalists voice, is that the Clintons provoke more scandals because they do more fishy stuff. â€Fishyâ€ here doesnâ€™t mean â€criminalâ€ or even â€unethical.â€ No one in the Obama camp, to my knowledge, actually thinks that Clinton used an offsite email service as part of some nefarious scheme to keep records from the public. But they do think itâ€™s really dumb to do anything that might be misconstrued by congressional Republicans as malfeasance and spark an investigation, especially when that thing youâ€™re doing is completely unnecessary. â€No Dramaâ€ Obama doesnâ€™t do stuff like give paid speeches at Goldman Sachs or chat up the head of the Justice Department when his wife is being investigated or keep around personally loyal aides who nonetheless provoke unnecessary   (like Philippe Reines or Sidney Blumenthal). He doesnâ€™t do it not because he thinks itâ€™s wrong but because itâ€™s imprudent; it gets in the way and makes it harder to get stuff done. So while Obama loyalists absolutely do not think that Clinton should be indicted or that she did anything wrong regarding Benghazi, you will sometimes hear them lament that the Clintons sometimes bring this stuff on themselves.    The trouble with the Clinton loyalistsâ€™ theory is that it encourages a fatalism about the war on the Clintons that causes complacency, and spurs the Clintons to do stuff that really does bring more criticism and scrutiny upon them than theyâ€™d endure if they were as careful as Obama has been. To hear the Clintons tell it, conservative   animus is a force of   scale and gravity. In 2004, Bill Clinton gave a speech following a screening of The Hunting of the President, a   documentary adapted from the book of the same name (subtitle: â€The   Campaign to Destroy Bill and Hillary Clintonâ€).  Both the book and film contend that Hillary Clintonâ€™s   assertion that there was a vast   conspiracy out to get her and Bill was literally true; that there really was a concerted effort from funders like Richard Mellon Scaife, outlets like the American Spectator, congressional Republicans, and the independent counselâ€™s office to take down the Clintons on   phony charges. In his speech, Clinton explains his scandals as the inevitable consequence of  â€™60s backlash to social liberalism, and as a natural byproduct of the end of the Cold War. â€When the Berlin Wall fell, the perpetual right in America, which always needs an enemy, didnâ€™t have an enemy anymore,â€ Clinton argues. â€So I had to serve as the next best thing. I think itâ€™s really important that you understand that.â€ If you believe you are being targeted with the same intensity as the Soviet Union, then the question of how you can change your behavior starts to feel like so much fiddling around the margins. Reporters whoâ€™ve spent time with Hillary Clinton find that sheâ€™s absorbed this view, that she and Bill feel they canâ€™t catch a break with the press, and so she isnâ€™t too concerned about taking actions that could exacerbate the problem.    â€Itâ€™s clear that even today she and her campaign feel that they canâ€™t win with the press, that the story lines about her are already written,â€ Rebecca Traister wrote in a New York magazine profile of Hillary Clinton in May. â€Itâ€™s a paranoiac cycle  â€”   Clinton and her team think that everyone is after her, and their behavior creates further incentive for everyone to come after her.â€ The Clintonsâ€™ targeting really is unusual             From the vantage point of 2016, the Clintonsâ€™ theory of their own persecution can seem   and almost pathologically distanced from their own actions. Even if you think the impeachment was an idiotic waste of the countryâ€™s time and resources, it remains the case that Bill Clinton never wouldâ€™ve been impeached if he hadnâ€™t slept with an intern and lied about it under oath. He didnâ€™t have to do that. The same, to a much lesser extent, with Hillary and the email server. The scandal is overblown, itâ€™s true, but she still couldâ€™ve avoided all this hassle and drama if sheâ€™d just used her official email account for all State Department business. But for the Clintons, everything from 1992 onward is part of the same ongoing saga, and it began way before they did anything particularly fishy at all. Bill slept with Gennifer Flowers? Not great, but a normal, survivable sex scandal. Whitewater? The Clintons did literally nothing wrong; it was all made up nonsense. Travelgate?   nonsense. Vince Foster?   nonsense. There was even a scandal about a haircut Bill Clinton got in 1993. â€You will never hear me criticize or complain about the press coverage I got in the aftermath of all the stuff that happened in â€™98 with my deposition in the Jones case,â€ he says in the Hunting of the President speech, alluding to the Lewinsky scandal. â€Iâ€™m talking about what happened before.â€ And what happened before is tough to explain in terms of the Clintonsâ€™ actions. Obamaâ€™s relationship with Tony Rezko is more suspicious than the Clintonsâ€™ role in Whitewater, yet it did not result in any federal investigation of Obama. Thatâ€™s a real discrepancy, one that has to be explained through historical context, through the unique status the Clintons have, and through the uniquely intense campaign to build up scandals relating to them. Bill Clinton is probably right that the Cold War made politics less   which, combined with the existence of the   independent counselâ€™s office, set the stage for a presidency constantly under investigation.    Thereâ€™s also something to be said for the Clintonsâ€™ DGAF attitude toward their scandals. One of the major failures of the Obama presidency was its hypercautious approach to appointments, requiring intense vetting that left key administration and judicial positions unfilled for too long. That was a direct result of his administrationâ€™s caution when it came to potential scandals, a caution the Clintons are willing to throw to the wind. The Clintonsâ€™ peculiar relationship with scandal did not begin with them being unusually sketchy characters. They werenâ€™t; they had flaws, but Bill Clinton in 1993 was no dirtier than Barack Obama in 2009. He was painted as much dirtier, though, and he and Hillary responded by adopting an assumption that the press would target them no matter what, and so a   secrecy,   and fatalism took hold. The result is a mutually reinforcing cycle, in which the particular historical circumstances of the 1990s created the image of the   Clintons, and the Clintons gave up on trying to erase that image, ensuring its perpetuation long after it shouldâ€™ve faded away. Politics is not set up to create presidencies like Bill Clintonâ€™s anymore, but the Clintons themselves are not set up to reap the benefits of that shift.  Benghazi, the attack and the scandal, explained
